ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 111 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 111 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would recommend this class if you want to learn how to hear easy music in your head, or to get better at figuring out the melody / chords you're hearing.

Musi 218 with Andrew Chung was a very effective way to do ear training. I feel much more confident in sight-singing, rhythmic and melodic dictation, etc. That said, if you've done some sight-singing and ear-training in the past, I'd recommend biting the bullet and taking 219 - even if you've never dealt with fixed-do before. In 218, the first 70% of the sight-singing examples are in C Major or A Minor; at the end you gradually transition to other keys. Granted, I feel that I have a super solid foundation in sight-singing now, but I do believe I could have survived 219 had I gone there directly. As for the keyboard lab component of this class, beware of high variations in the amount of work between sections (which are sorted by ability level). I'm a pianist so I was put in a more advanced section for keyboard lab with Prof. Stuart Duncan, even though I was absolutely new to reading figured bass. So the pace of the keyboard lab was slightly overwhelming at first. Nonetheless, I survived, and overall I'd say the workload for this course was very manageable. There's only one gripe I have about this class, but it's a major one: the textbook. I bought a hard copy for well over $100, and it was an absolute ripoff. If your instructor allows it (like Andrew did), just buy the Kindle edition and share that with a classmate. At no point in the class did I feel that having a hard copy was necessary or even beneficial. For instance, when we were doing melodic dictations, Andrew had to give us the key/time signatures, etc, because the book failed to provide that information. The book literally had *blank staff paper* for melodic dictations. Then what's the point of buying the book as opposed to printing out blank staff paper?? Also - the book claims that it unlocks access to great online ear-training tools that you can use at home for practice. In reality, literally none of the tools on the website work (on ANY browser, on ANY computer - I tried!). Moreover, the website didn't require any access code...so even if the website did work, I wouldn't have needed the book to use the online learning tools. TL;DR: I strongly recommend the class for a basic foundation in ear training and figured bass reading. But don't buy the textbook.
